What a fun interview - it was very human! Time to check out the inflation video.

The Hubble distance says the universe is 13.8 billion years old.  If the current model of string theory is true, the period of rapid expansion would have to have occurred over the estimated average distance between stars.  That would yield a universe that is much younger than the 13.8 current prediction.  We can however see 46 billion YEARS into the past so we know that the universe is more than that age.  To account for this discrepancy, some have argued that the fabric of space is expanding, however, this would yield a speed of light that is different depending on your relative speed when compared to the expansion of the fabric of space.  Local objects do not move apart based on the redshift  predictions because it has been argued that gravity holds them together.  The rate of expansion relative to the fabric of space would yield a speed of light relative to us which is different than the speed of light relative to stars which supposedly are moving apart. The redshift is caused by friction between aether particles.  I showed a flaw in the Michelson Morley experiment that allows for the existence of a luminiferous aether.
